Geez, I don't know guys... Is it really possible to wage war on science? I mean, science is a practice -- a methodology humans use to help them understand how they exist in relation to the world and universe around them. You can't really attack a practice, at least not from a critical and intellectual standpoint.

Now, you can attack people who perform a practice (or through a methodology you disagree with), but you can't actually attack the practice/methodology itself. At best, you can critically examine practices and compare them to others, to see if there are any weak points or blind spots in them, and then offer alternative methods or solutions in the event that there are critical errors in the methodology in question.

Now is it fair to say that at an institutional level, science might be under attack? Well, no... not really (even though that's what you're essentially saying in this video).

A better way to phrase it might be "People are no longer blindly yielding to the dictates and determinations of institutional science -- that is, the body of individuals and the systems they've achieved and perform through, which (presumably) seek to represent, perform maintenance on, and then speak on behalf of the practice of science." Humans have been using practices and methodologies for actualization (agricultural methods, tools, and the such) for millenniums now -- well before the scientific "banner" came along, and sought to collectivize these things under its heading.

To claim science is under attack would be fundamentally no different than claiming religion is under attack -- which would be a false statement. No, no... the authority of the institution is being called into question, but not the practice itself. Much in the same way science exposes critical errors in religion, so too does critical thinking expose conceptual errors in science. Only, the practices of both religion and science remain unaffected by conceptual errors in their respective bodies. In other words, the practices themselves don't take offense to people calling their authority into question. It's the PEOPLE that perform through them who take offense to others calling into question the authority of the institution.

The institution of science is not being revered in the way it (or those who feel empowered through it) want(s) to be. The only thing I could think to liken it to would be a father complaining about his wife not appreciating him, and his children not listening to him. Would it be fair, no, accurate, for the father to claim he was being attacked simply because he felt undervalued, and felt his authority wasn't being recognized? I don't think so. To claim such a thing would technically be unscientific.

A real war science would look something more like people dressing in animal furs, and using sticks and rocks to effectively stamp out all traces of technology and social learning, which would extend to languages and then all aspects of modern humanity. Paradoxically, a real war on science would require more science than is presently available to humanity, because truly regressing us to a point where science was not (in some people's opinion) 'the bane of existence' would require a sorting process that is exponentially more advanced than science presently is.

“Science is a wonderful thing if one does not have to earn one’s living at it. One should earn one’s living by work of which one is sure one is capable. Historically, it is the power of the country that dictates scientific progress: the Egyptian proto-science sages during the Egyptian dynasties; Greek philosophers, in the Greek golden age; library of Alexandria, amid the height of Rome; England during Newton and Boyle; the rise of Leiden University in the 18th century Netherlands, France during the Renaissance; the German geniuses of Berlin; American presently peaked with Gibbs, Feynman, and Hirata. This video claims to represent the causes of science, yet fails to do some incredibly basic research. OK let's do a bit of fact checking here:

1) "The Federal Banks Bailout is more than the budget of NASA in its entire history" - Yes, when unadjusted for inflation. If you adjust for inflation, you'd see that NASA's budget is more. Not by much, but the difference is that bailed out companies have returned the money to the US government, with interest. This is called 'cherry picking of data' and is one of the things you learn to NOT do in grade 4 science. Always convert to the right units, always account for error.

2) "The Roman Empire fell because they didn't respect Greek science" - Wrong, holy shit so fucking wrong, and even shits on the Scientific Method. You formed a hypothesis, what was your methodology? Where is the research to support your statement? Because if you did do research, you'd find that the Romans are the masters of adapting good ideas. Their engineering products are still around today, from the aqueduct to straight roads to the hydraulic pressure mines of Spain. Do you know why the Acropolis of Athens is still standing, despite countless bombs from Ottoman, Greek, British and German forces? Well, we know that the surviving parts of the Acropolis look more modern than its surroundings. Guess who made the refurbishments in 100AD? Romans. Do you know who made the first cement structures? Romans. What about glass-blowing? Oh the Romans perfected it! What about the Cornalvo Dam, which is still in use today? Romans did that.

To say that Romans don't adhere to science is to shit on the science of history to the highest degree.

3) "The UK science budget has fallen to 0.5% of GDP". Yes, through concepts called "inflation" and "the British economy growing at an annualized rate of 2% for the past 5 years". Should the budget be increased? Totally. Was the budget cut? No. The UK science budget was 'ring-fenced' back in 2010. Again, cherry picking of data and being incredibly disingenious.

You end your video with "you have to rely on facts to make opinions", yet you're doing exactly what these 'opponents of science' are doing: by relying on your preconceived notions and biases to make shitty opinions and then try to convince others of your own wrong facts in a video. Scientific racism was the justification behind the Scramble for Africa that completely eliminated all African identity, the slave labor conditions of India during the British Empire, the near eradication of the Aboriginals in Australia, the mistreatment of Native Americans in the United States, and most damning was the rise of the Nazi party formulated on the idea that the Caucasians were the highest evolved human beings, and all other human beings such as the Jews simply held us down.

Another example can be found in the Climategate scandal. During this scandal, we received evidence of lots of scientific bias in the climatology community, talking about boycotting certain journals for publishing papers that went against their narrative, outright avoiding FOIA requests, and outright blasting anyone who publishes a paper that goes against their views. These things are clearly wrong and the wrongdoing was done by some of the top what we called climate scientists.

This does not mean to blindly reject scientists. What that means is that we should not accept what any person, be they a scientist or politician, based on dogma. The general public has every right, and definitely deserves that right, to demand evidence fit for their own personal standards. The Romans were simply content with Greek discoveries?

This is another reason I disliked the video, false statements. The Romans brought us many advances, such as how to structure cities and societal roles. We had the first social programs, highways, architectural and agricultural improvements. People didn't stop thinking with the Romans. Roman culture was more practical and less philosophical, which brought us applied knowledge. It is applied science where the Greeks lacked it (after all, neither Socrates or Plato, as smart as they were, could come up with ways to reduce disease or prevent their own people from devolving into Chaos).

Government funding of science?

If you correct for inflation, we have spent more on NASA than its discoveries can ever hope to repay, especially considering that many of these discoveries would have been made by private individuals anyway.

Government funded research should be based on current productivity, NOT based on simple satisfaction of curiosity. For those who are saying things like "evolution's JUST A THEORY" then look up the word theory. A scientific theory is as close as possible to fact that can exist. It's not a hypothesis. A theory has been repeatedly tested and confirmed through the scientific method. A hypothesis is an unproven idea. A scientific theory is proven. They may change, or the way they are interpreted may change, but the facts don't. For instance, we have a huge amount of evidence in population traits becoming more or less common over time. That's evolution. That is a fact. However, the way we think all of the facts separately may go together can change.

And to those saying "I've never seen a dog turn into a cat, so macroevolution can't be real BLEH"

Get out. Microevolution is IDENTICAL to macroevolution. They are just terms on separate scales. Microevolution happens on a small scale, within a population. Macroevolution occurs when this happens over and over until the changes have transcended the boundaries of a single species.

Imagine it with a dog; if dogs are bred until the fur changes colour, that would be microevolution. But imagine doing that over and over and over a huge amount of times until it in essence, stops being a dog. Imagine breeding only those with shorter teeth, or different shaped heads, or different fur thickness. Eventually, the results could no longer be classified as dogs. Eventually there would be too much of a difference in the genetic code. The differences in the genetic structure is so different that it no longer can be classified as a dog. That is, in very simplistic terms, macroevolution.

That is why many biologists don't even use these terms. There's no point. When they do occasionally use the terms, it's just for descriptive reasons. So to any creationists trying to make a magic line between these two words; stop. There is no line. They are the same.

Okay, fucking hell. AsapSCIENCE, I love you guys, but I hate bad history more. The collapse of the Roman Empire had nothing to do with values shifting away from science - it couldn't have. The damn Eastern half was culturally Greek, and the elites of the Western half borderline idolized Greek civilization. Regardless, it's not as though the Rome simply stopped making scientific advancements. Just a small list here: Roman Pentaspastos ("Five-pulley-crane"), double glazed concrete, glass-blowing, Roman abacus, the Screw press, advanced large-scale architecture, the codex, brass-making, hydraulic mining, the hydrometer, and a number of surgical instruments which we still use today were all invented in Rome. This is just a fraction of what the created. I'm going to blatantly steal from a historian here, and post what he said about whether the Romans stagnated technologically:

"No. Absolutely not. Even in parts of the academic community there is a continued perception that the Roman empire stagnated technologically, mainly because their social values forbade wealth from other means than agriculture. This is, of course, complete bunk. The idea only comes from a few passages from literature, which was written by the imperial elites, for the imperial elites (the size of the Senate was 600 people during the Empire, the population of the empire as a whole was 50-70 million). It was also a presentation of an ideal, rather than a reality, because the elites often collected money through rent. So don't listen to that argument.
So, where did the Romans technologically innovate? Everywhere. The problem is that the Romans never identified the uses of coal, so their technology was still essentially water powered. For example, a sawmill for cutting stone seen on second century tomb in Hierapolis is mechanically almost identical to James' Watt's steam engine, only it is powered by water rather than steam. We have tentatively identified the remains of a few of these in several parts of the Empire. In some farm houses we have been able to identify several very impressive gear based water mills, and the more we look for them the more we find.
Mining is another area where the Romans innovated greatly. The primary technical problem with mining is the water table, because you can't mine under water. Before Roman times, mining operations were essentially stuck only mining down to there, but the Romans were able to go far further down. In fact, old Roman mines were only reopened in the later 19th century because they didn't have the technology to go deeper than the Romans until then. Look up the Roman water wheels in the Rio Tinto mines--they were incredibly sophisticated. There was also some pretty impressive works to divert river courses to help in mining.
Roman shipbuilding was largely based on Hellenistic innovations, but took those farther than ever before. Roman anchors are basically identical to those from the nineteenth century. Modern style bilge pumps, lanteen rigging, and extremely strong hauls were also present.
Construction was another area the Romans excelled in. I can't find the best picture for it, but they made innovated use of pulleys to create their stunning constructions. Their innovations with cement and the arch are also well known.
I'm sure there are other areas I can't think of now, but basically speaking the Roman empire was a period of heavy technology use."
